captions.text: This is Delos!

She's an Amel Super Maramu
built in La Rochelle, France
in the year 2000.

She's a 53 foot sloop rigged
ketch and has been my home for
the past 6 years.

Delos and her crew have sailed
a lot of miles since leaving
Seattle, and she's taken great
care of us.

"Are you ready? Alright, let's
go!"
"First off!"
Is the dive gear

over here we have the lovely
Brady Trautman

And we have our 5 tanks on
board.

Brady is our dive master you
could say,

"See, like Josje said we have 5
tanks on board..
5 full sets of gear,

and probably enough parts to fix a full dive shop I think!"
"yeah, we have a lot of stuff!"

"We fix quite a few things over
the past couple of years..

of course we have a compressor,
because we dive in a lot of
crazy locations where you can't
get air fills

And each tank only takes about
20 minutes to fill

Which is approximately 50c of
diesel!
"We now have..
fishing rods!

So fishing is pretty crucial on
Delos

We try and get as much fishing
in as we can.

We got one fishing rod on the
starboard and one over on port

And we also have this little
guy here, this is our hand line
And we mainly catch Mahi-mahi,
Yellow-fin tuna and Wahoo.
In varying sizes!
And these guys are solar panels!

They are VERY VERY important on
Delos!

Originally we just had the two
outside which equaled up to 400
watts

We added up the centre one,
which is another 200 watts, so
it gave us a total of 600 watts!

For the whole solar. Capacity
of the boat.

It's amazing, we don't have to
run the generator at all, for
any electricity to charge the
batteries.

It's only for dive tanks,
making water and making hot
water

if we decide to take hot showers"
"Very rarely we do this.."

"Also, over here, we have our
BBQ!"

"Which is used on very special
occasions, like today!

Which is the 4th of July! So
Happy America Day!"

"Karin's got some lovely
looking steaks here!"

"Yep, we'll cook up some steaks
for tonight! We also have our
lovely sun chairs..
They are just amazing

for sunny days!"
"Yeah, they're pretty good"

"So, shall we carry on? Up to
the bow?"
"Follow me"

"Oh, these are our surfboards
by the way!

We have two longboards here on
the port side. We also have two
shortboards over on starboard
side there

So we have four surfboards on
board, which is pretty cool.
Surfboard on board!

"Now we are back in the cockpit
where we started"

"This is pretty much our living
room! If you could call it
that.. pretty much

We spend most of our time in
here

when we're sailing. Got it all
decked out

with comfy cushions, and what
not.. and sunscreen, cos that's
really important!

And the most important part of
the boat

Is the Captian's chair with the
wheel, and all the instruments
that makes us go places!

So here's lovely Captian Brian, and his American things he's got going on!
(laughing)

"Boxer shorts.."
"Pretty sure it's undies.."

"You improvise on the sail
boat, so this is what we do"

As far as sailboats go, it's
pretty comfy

and in a nice dry, protected
environment, not stuck out the
back

where every wave is gonna hit
ya, but there's a nice hard
dodger here to keep you out of
the wind,

and the elements of the rain
and all that stuffs real good.

We have all the instruments
that you need here to sail.

So on this monitor right here
we've got a pretty sweet little
navigation system that gives us
our GPS

position on top of our charts,
with radar overlay, and all the
sailing

information that we need, for
all routing, and course
plotting, really really cool
stuff.

This little guy is just a life
saver. This is our auto-pilot.
Our trusting magnetic compass

so if all goes hay-wire, we can
kinda go, cut this direction

we have a pretty general idea
of where we are, and can get
around with just that.

We've got our engine
instruments over here. So when
there's no wind,

and we're coming in to a
marina, or a harbour, we can
crank up what we call

The iron genny and cruise
around with that.

Delos is kind of like a big
piggy boat to drive around

not very maneuverable, so we
have bow thruster

so to make us go port, and
starboard, and raise it and
lower it which is pretty cool.

It's blowing a pretty fresh 20
knots right now, keeping
everything nice and cool.

We're at anchor, so our boat
speed is down to 0 knots and
the wind is right off of our bow

We're in 4 metres of water and
have about 34 metres of chain.

And this little control panel
here is how we pick up the
anchor.

We can put the anchor out, or
pull her in.

We have control for all the
sails, and the furlers, and the
winches

to put out the genoa and the
main sail, without leaving the
cockpit

which is really nice on those
nasty stormy days,

so it's a real comfortable boat to sail!"
"Definitely!"

"So, what do you say we go
downstairs?"

"So this is the main living
space, down below on Delos.

And it's right next to the
Galley.

Which is really nice, because
it kind of creates a whole
social space.

We're pretty lucky on Delos,
because we have a washer and
dryer

for clothes, and we have some
pretty typical stuff
microwave, propane oven,
But we also have a dishwasher!

Which is not very common to
boats

This is our water maker which
makes almost 200 litres an hour
for washing and drinking.
And then of course, our fridge!
As a primary freezer for food

So this is where we keep all of
our frozen meats,

and we have lots of canned
foods,
some milk
and some rum!

If we look in here, we've got
our beer reserves, which is
actually running a little bit
low

so we're gonna have to stock up
pretty soon.

On Delos, we do enjoy drinking
beer

so we have a dedicated beer
fridge!
Oh yeah!

Red Horse Extra Strong from the
Phillipines. Awesome stuff!

We do have a projector. And
then across the way here..
Is our screen!

So this is where we have people
stay when we have guests,

or when Brady and Josje on
board. It's pretty nice, we get
a lot of breeze up here
and we have two bunks

you can sleep on the port side,
one on the starboard side.

(laughing)
Up forward, we have

a head. So it's got pretty
typical
bathroom stuff.
We have electric toilets.

"Let's go and check out the
back!"
So here is our pass-through bunk

Go through here, and you will
come down to our master suite
in the back!

Map of the world here, showing
our track, planning on where we
go

Also have some pictures of
family and friends

And this is the second head on
the boat

This also has a shower and
everything
This is our navigation station

so here we have our single side
band radio, the VHF,

and some of the sailing
instruments

Up here we have our cool
control panels. This is the 24
volt panel
Runs all the DC things.

Then this is our 120 volt
panel, for air conditioning,

and water maker, battery
chargers, outlets, microwaves,
things like that.
We also have the engine room.
Down here in the cockpit!

"Brian spends about 20% of his
time down here..

he is our handy man on the
boat! I don't know what we
would without him, because he
fixes a lot of things

"Yeah, I don't know, Brain, you
explain what's down here"

"There's all the heart of the
boat down here. So we've got
the main diesel right here..

which is a volvo penta diesel,
to get us around
when there's no wind blowing.

Right behind me is our
generator. It's a 7 kilowatt
diesel powered onan generator

and after we put in the solar
panels, we really don't have to
run this

to make electricity. It's
mainly for running the water
maker

and for filling dive tanks. So
if you look right over here..

we've got our awesome dive
compressors

So, this thing has just saved
us so much

in being able to dive anywhere
in the world where there's not
a dive shop filling our tanks

And then back over here, we've
got pump for air conditioning

and our dieselinator over in
the corner that turns salt water

into fresh water so we can take
showers

and not have to worry about
filling up water at a dock.
We've got battery chargers

And power inverters that turn
DC into AC

I see power and pumps and all
sorts of good stuff
I spend a lot of time down here"

comments.text:
Just got a 20' Oday here in MI, of course now I have dreams of sailing 
around the world - with a strong focus on the area's you guys traveled. I 
feel like the video's are giving me even more inspiration and a view into 
the "how to" of it all. Really enjoying the video's thanks for taking the 
time to record, edit and what not. You guys are my sailing hero's. ;-)﻿
comments.author: Spencer Covey

comments.text:
Beautiful boat! I'm curious about the water system. Does the desalinator 
also purify the water for you? Do you ever have to consider the source 
before you fill your onboard tanks?﻿
comments.author: MisterLumpkin

comments.text:
+MisterLumpkin So our Desalinator does in fact purify the water.  The 
reverse osmosis membranes are small enough they get rid of most bacteria 
and nasties in the water, then we have yet another carbon filter for 
drinking water.  We only run it in open, clean water and never when there 
are other boats with open holding tanks nearby (or in muddy rivers).  We 
carry about 1,000 liters so can go a week or two without needing to run the 
water maker.  It is a big one and makes almost 200 liters per hour.  We've 
only had to fill the tanks from a land source once when our watermaker 
broke so really hasn't been too much of an issue so far.  Fair Winds, and 
thanks so much for watching!  Brian SV Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

you just mention somewhere up in borneo..what the river name.im live in

comments.author: steward nanang

comments.text:
Hi there I love your series. I ama Brit expat in Bavaria stay at home Dad 
tied down but did the travel thing  a few years before having kids.

I spent 5 years adventre of a lifetime mapping coral reefs and habitats in 
the Arabian Gulf Kuwait border to Dhahran Also coral reefs in the Red Sea. 
I spent a lot of time on Boston Whalers and Zodiacs chasing turtles on a 
Dacor Seasprint, mapping mangroves and spotting dolphins - huge fun. my 
colleagues were Filipinos and they were huge fun. Their laughter was 
infectious.

Love the bikins too. can one of them buy a British Union Jack bikini and 
we'll name her a Spice Girl?﻿
comments.author: Jeremy Stocks

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply! So you are in port now then? I'd loev to see some of 
your film on coral bleaching. When I mapped the Red Sea off Jizan in 1998 
the coral was to a large extent dead. The Arabian Gulf has a problem with 
this too.
comments.author: Jeremy Stocks

comments.text:
+Jeremy Stocks Oh cool man, sounds like an epic time!  We were in the 
Philippines for 8 months and just starting to work on those videos now :)  
Such and amazing place and people!  Incredible diving there as well....  
Hmmmm- I'll submit the request for Bikin's and we'll see what we can do :)  
Fair Winds, and thanks for watching!  Brian SV Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Are you able to get internet and tv onboard or do you have to do all that 
when you get to shore. I hear somehow you can get internet almost anywhere 
in the world but maybe that's really expensive.﻿
comments.author: suckmyassloser

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos
 A G per G! i thought verizon was expensive.
comments.author: Tyler Romig

comments.text:
+suckmyassloser Yea we actually have a marine SSB (Ham radio) that can be 
used with a Pactor Modem to send and receive emails through relay stations 
around the world, as well as voice.  It's worked great everywhere 
even 1'000's of miles from land and is completely free after you get the 
equipment!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Thanks for answering. My guess is gps navigation is a whole 
other system and hopefully affordable to use. I think I've seen you 
listening to the radio so wonder if you use a ham radio and wonder what 
kind of luck you have receiving or sending signals in the ocean.
comments.author: suckmyassloser

comments.text:
You can get BGAN (Broadband Global Access Network) but it's super 
expensive.  Last time I checked it was like $1,000 per GB!  Anyway we just 
go without, then when we get to a port we buy a local SIM card and just use 
3G.  So far it's been working great and we have some connectivity in some 
really sweet places.  Thanks for watching :)  Brian S/V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Hello Brian that looks like a sweet boat, I am a big fan of you guys and 
what you do. I wish I could do that some day Im 16 and im into diving and 
sailing and learning how to sail. Brian could you tell me what brand that 
boat is and what´s the top speed I will appreciate it a lot! Thanks Brian 
keep on posting vídeos you inspire me to keep sailing!!﻿
comments.author: Ricardo Andrés González

comments.text:
Brian, I am setting my boat up right now.  Thinking about electronics at 
the moment and I couldn't help but notice that huge monitor you've got up 
there!  Is that connected to a PC?  Is it touchscreen?  Have been looking 
at MFD's and Radar, can't decide between Raymarine and Navico.  Maybe PC is 
the solution!﻿
comments.author: Bradley Stevenson

comments.text:
+Bradley Stevenson Hey Bradley!  Yes, that monitor is connected to a laptop 
that lives down below.  I have it split to two mirrored displays, one 
running at the nav station and one in the cockpit.  The monitor is a 
touchscreen, sunlight readable, weather proof unit made by planar.  Check 
out http://www.planar.com/solutions/industrial/ .  It's a few years old, 
and at that time was the only option.  If I were to buy a new one now I 
would seriously look into some of the new tablets\pads out there.  If you 
have any other questions feel free to send us an email at 
svdelos53@gmail.com .Fair Winds and thanks for watching!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: Wow that is an amazingly well kitted out boat!﻿
comments.author: Justin Rens

comments.text:
Beautiful rig, I can understand how you can call it home. Looks like a lot 
of work though.﻿
comments.author: J Houdy

comments.text:
+J Houdy
Hey!  So the original plan was to set sail for just under 2 years.  I fell 
in love with the lifestyle and couldn't really see myself doing anything 
else.  So, we all pitched in and found a way to stretch the budget.  I 
wrote a few blog posts about this- check out 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-1by-brian.html 
and 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-2-by-brian.html 
if you have a few minutes.

Thanks for watching!

Fair Winds,
Brian
S\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
I am curious, how do you afford living off the grid for 500 days? (I'm 
still watching and envious so it could be more)
comments.author: J Houdy

comments.text:
+J Houdy Oh yea, it is a bit of work but the worst day working on the boat 
is still better than my old office job :)  Thanks so much for 
watching!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Hi Guys.. Just stumbled across your channel .. work just took a back seat 
as i now sit fantasising about my own need to soon buy a boat, throw the 
lines and head off towards SE Asia.. So impressed with Delos and your 
travel shares. The sketch artwork video intro's are as inspiring as the 
passages you are making. I would love to know more about S/VDelos and hear 
any advice you could offer in what to look for when swapping house for 
sails for a lifetime of adventure cruising?
Again, thanks for the posts, following your adventures is my new hobby :)﻿
comments.author: paul capon

comments.text:
+paul capon Hey Paul! Awesome to hear that this is a dream you have.  I can 
tell you it's a completely amazing life and sometimes I look back at all 
the little things that got me here and just smile :)  Swapped the house, 
car, etc. and went all in to get Delos.  I did write a few blog posts about 
the initial stuff and some financial things that may be helpful.  Check out 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-1by-brian.html 
and 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-2-by-brian.html 
if you have a few minutes.Thanks so much for taking the time to follow the 
adventure..  More videos on the way so stay tuned :)Fair Winds,BrianS\V 
Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Gorgeous boat and awesome lifestyle, I am sure it comes with it's fair 
share of challenges but still the end rewards are priceless.
Envy from Canada, stuck in traffic on way to work :)﻿
comments.author: Nick Dawn

comments.text:
+Mark Hercun Hey Mark- True words....  Everything is always a balance.  
Sometimes sailing can be challenging, exhausting, and a little scary.  On 
the other hand you get back x10 in pure awesomeness.  Thanks so much for 
watching, and good luck with the traffic.  I remember those days stuck 
commuting on my way into Seattle......Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
I have been toying with the this idea (sailing around from here to where 
ever) for a few years now ! this is so inspiring to see that it is possible 
and you are doing it! I wish i could leave tomorrow.﻿
comments.author: MrMobok

comments.text:
+MrMobok Oh man, well glad to hear that the seed is planted and growing :)  
It took me about 4 years to put the plan together.  Things really fell into 
place during that time and I felt very fortunate!  Wishing you the best of 
luck in following your dreams.Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
This is my dream, but alas, it's generally a rich old man's game. What do 
you guys do for a living that you can afford to own such a beautiful yacht?﻿
comments.author: Dionysus Leonidas

comments.text:
+Dionysus Leonidas Hey Dionysys!  I know what you mean but the times are a' 
changin :)  There are plenty of affordable cruising boats out there and you 
can live very, very cheaply!  I wrote a few blogs on how we afford to sail 
on Delos.  Maybe check out 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-1by-brian.html 
and 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-2-by-brian.html 
.Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: hey Philippines represent! Tanduay and Red Horse lol how y'all likin it?﻿
comments.author: bulok69

comments.text:
+bulok69 Philippines is completely, mind blowingly awesome!  We ended up 
staying 8 months there.  So beautiful and amazingly friendly people.  Can't 
wait to start working on the Philippines videos.  We have some awesome 
footage!Thanks for watching :)Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Great crossing.  Love the adventure!  Are you using Amateur Radio on board? 
 If so what frequency to you monitor?

Safe travels. ﻿
comments.author: Robert Chambers

comments.text:
+Robert Chambers Hey Robert!  Yup, we have an ICOM-M710 marine SSB and I 
have my HAM license.  We usually only use it for a few minutes at a time to 
save power though, unless we schedule a time\frequency to try and talk to 
someone.Fair Winds, and thanks for watching!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: Love your videos guys. But how on earth do you get the dinghy on deck???﻿
comments.author: 30calRover

comments.text:
+30calRover So we have a lifting harness attached at 4 points that we 
made.  We then use a utility halyard from the top of the main mast and just 
hoist it straight up and onto the cradle on the foredeck, using one of the 
winches on the main mast.  We hoist it up with the engine, fuel tank, etc.  
It's a quick job and great exercise!  Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Simply the most enjoyable way I can think of to see the world. You guys are 
inspiring, really.﻿
comments.author: Lamar Williamson

comments.text:
Nice trip guys I have envy of your trip, who´s knows maybe in another life 
I could do something like that, nice music and nice narrative you transmit 
perfectly what the trip means for the crew, a lot of adventures and a lot 
of fun, enjoy the life. Just in case if some spot of the DELOS trip comes 
to Ecuador let me know, as well I recommend Galapagos 100%﻿
comments.author: guerraji

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Hi Brian thanks to respond my comments and for the friendly 
spirit, yesterday I have time to watching some of the first episodes of 
your trip and to understand better the actual conditions of the DELOS is 
good to see chapter 15 to see what happen with her after 10 months upper 
the docks, was awesome all the work that you made it how did you learn all 
that stuff you are mechanic, taylor, electrical engineer, computer guy, 
carpenter, financial manager, and I could believe a hundred more things 
also a Sailor and Party man congrats of the skills, and your crew made 
crazy excellent work too, I could understood a bit because I´m a old cars 
restorer, mechanic, work in electrical stuff,my house handyman, gadgets and 
computer silly, surfer and diver, and orthodontist but with 2 skills that 
you don't have yet husband and father of 2 rascals. How long do you have 
sailing?? this is something that I want to learn as a sea lover. Say Hi to 
all your crew and good winds, enjoy the life and take care, all the best 
for all of you
comments.author: guerraji

comments.text:
+guerraji Thanks so much for the awesome comment!  Really good to hear, 
makes us inspired to put together more videos :)  We missed the Galapagos 
on this trip because we left from Mexico to head to the Marquesas but next 
time we do it for sure!Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Wow, nice tour, really sweet rig.
All the best
VP﻿
comments.author: Vagabond Phil

comments.text:
Question.. Will Brady and Josje going to be back? We have really enjoyed 
the 4 of you over the years and really enjoyed your adventures very much. 
Your personality really shine through which has made it very interesting. 
Well I wish you all the very best.﻿
comments.author: Jack Frowein

comments.text:
+Jack Frowein Hey Jack, thanks so much for the nice comments!  We've had so 
much fun on the trip and get along so well I suppose that can't help but 
come through in the footage.  Hopefully they'll be back on board after they 
stash some cash away.  But all our plans are written in sand at low tide so 
we never know that the future holds......  Anyway, if you haven't seen this 
blog yet about what they've been up to maybe check it out 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2014/07/5-months-laterby-brady-and-josje.htmlFair 
Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
wow! I have not been able to watch you all in while; but got home from the 
sailing one class this am. Started thinking about you all got youtube. 
can't stop watching. love it.
May I ask about how much would a boat like that run with all the toys.? 
just so I can tell the class. please keep making the video & also you might 
put them on Vimeo.com they are a little lay back about stuff like music & 
nudity. Happy sailing from Kansas city
John T﻿
comments.author: John Maddux

comments.text:
+John Maddux Hey John- Cool man, glad to hear you're doing the sailing 
class!  So Delos is comparable to a fairly decent house.  Basically I 
traded in my house in Seattle when I got Delos.  Here are some recent 
listings to give you an actual idea:  
http://www.yachtworld.com/boats/category/type/Amel/Super+Maramu+2000  .  
Plenty more videos coming so stay tuned, and thanks so much for 
watching!Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: I love this! Thanks! Bloody Brilliant.﻿
comments.author: jasequick

comments.text: Wow impressive! ﻿
comments.author: Echo Affliction

comments.text: Very nice boat, good for you folks, enjoy!!...and thanks for sharing. ﻿
comments.author: Robert Bennett

comments.text: Beautiful Vessel! What is the size of you house battery bank?﻿
comments.author: bowedtoothdoc

comments.text:
+bowedtoothdoc We have 800AH at 12V, basically 8x 100AH.  But since we're a 
24V system we have them wired in series so it's really 400AH at 24V. Same 
difference.  Seems to be plenty of juice for our needs.  Thanks for 
watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: what is the name of the song at the beginning of this vid? ﻿
comments.author: nameless4284

comments.text:
+nameless4284 Actually check out Ramukanji music video. instead.  I think 
it's a better video!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
+nameless4284 Hey!  That would be Ramukanji by OneTox.  Check out Onetox- 
Ramukanji (2011 official remix). .  Thanks for watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Gosh you guys really have the perfect life (on Youtube anyways ^^)! I read 
some of the economics on your blog but I am a bit curious for the timeframe 
on the mortgage loan. That is really the only fixed cost for you right?

Oh and btw Brian I just wanna give you a tip on a really cool Swedish 
sailor named "Yrvind", he has been sailing all around the world in insanely 
small boats which he build himself. 

http://www.yrvind.com/ Maybe Karin has heard of him?

In any case you really are an inspiration and I wish you all the best!﻿
comments.author: Alfred Lingstrom

comments.text:
Hey Alfred- Thanks so much for watching!  Of course you can also count 
routine maintenance and insurance as a fixed cost I suppose.  For a marine 
mortgage you can do 20 years so it's quite similar to a house mortgage.  
Fair Winds!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: Great video of the vessel.﻿
comments.author: Bill Creadon

comments.text:
Do you guys ever get mail ( snail mail) just wondering if anyone ever sent 
you guys care packages? My daughters school sent some to the troops, as 
part of a geography project but she has watched some of the videos and 
likes you adventures. ﻿
comments.author: Joe Caley

comments.text:
+Joe Caley Hey Joe!  Actually we move around so often we never are really

counts so thank you very much!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: Delos is a great looking boat.  Love your videos.﻿

comments.text: What a life!﻿

comments.text: What a fantastic boat. It's a dream. Must be great for you all.﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Faldrian | Auch Let's Play Oh thanks so much for the comment!  More coming

comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: A Truly Awesome Vessel And Crew Cheers Kenny ﻿
comments.author: KVUSMC / Kenneth W Viar Jr

comments.text: Keep The Videos Coming Ya'll
comments.author: KVUSMC / Kenneth W Viar Jr

comments.text: hey man what kind of spare parts for engine bay stuff do you keep on hand?﻿
comments.author: Matt Alisch

comments.text:
+Matt Alisch Hey Matt!  So here is a pretty basic list off the top of my 
head:  spare belts (alternator and water pump for both main diesel and 
generator), spare salt water impellers, enough oil and filters for two oil 
changes for both, spare fuel filters, spare timing belt, spare water pump, 
spare engine coolant, heat exchanger caps, bilge pump, plenty of water 
maker pre-filters, spare fresh water pump, spare electric fan motors for 
hot air exhaust, dive compressor filters (and oil).  Plus lot's of random 
bits and pieces I've picked up over the years.  If you have any specific 
questions on a particular system feel free to email at 
svdelos53@gmail.com.  Fair Winds, and thanks for watching!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Haha, Brian you guys seem like the chillest dudes ever man! Dude that 
engine room is stacked with all kinds of hook-ups. How did you learn to 
work all of that or hook all of that up man? I imagine that would cost a 
lot of dough to install all of that if Demos didn't have it when you guys 
first got it.

Also, Tanduay rum and Red Horse are good shit! My mom is from the 
Philippines and last time I visited, I got shit-faced almost every night 
from all of that. Lol 

These videos rule man. Thanks!﻿
comments.author: W.N. Squeers

comments.text:
+W.N. Squeers
Oh right on! We actually spent quite a bit of time down in southern Negros 
and did the whale shark adventure at Oslob.  Also took Delos to Siquijor 
and Bohol.  Amazing places!  Oh man, I can't wait to get working on those 
videos.  We have some AWESOME footage from the Philippines.
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Awesome! Looking forward to that and your other vids. My mom is from Negros 
Oriental, which is an island next to the island of Cebu, where they have 
those whale sharks. Glad you guys had a great time there. There are great 
dive spots around Siquijor Island and around Dumaguete in general, both of 
which are located in the central Visayan region of the Philippines.
comments.author: W.N. Squeers

comments.text:
+W.N. Squeers Oh yea lot's of good stuff in that little room.  I learned 
mostly by breaking stuff then fixing it- sort of the school of hard 
knocks.  Sometimes it works out in my favor, other times I need to do it 
again but I have learned so much over time it's really been a lot of 
fun!yea man- the Philippines rules.  Such amazing people there.  Such a 
good spirit, always happy.  We really want to go back somtime.  Where in 
the PI is your mom from?  We're about to start working on the Philippines 
videos so stay tuned :)
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Sorry, I meant to say Delos not "Demos" lol

Boat looks very clean.
comments.author: W.N. Squeers

comments.text: Great to see the boat in more detail. Where is Delos going next?﻿
comments.author: Joe Caley

comments.text:
+Joe Caley Hey Joe- So Delos will be headed down the West coast of Borneo 
to Brunei, then we'll cross over to the mainland and chill in Thailand for 
a bit early next year.  We love Thai food so really looking forward to 
that.  Thanks for watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
though most of this had been shown over many of the previous episodes, I'm 
glad you decided to do this video, hopefully one day you can do a video 
that is more technical and more in depth with regards to the boat and gear. 
 Once again, well done and Thank you for sharing!   May you all always have 
fair winds and following seas.﻿
comments.author: Izzy Bocanegra
SV Delos Crew

comments.text: What are your GPS coordinates atm?﻿
comments.author: James Edmund

comments.text:
+James McSweeney Hey James- We try to keep our position updated on the blog 
using the SSB radio so check this link out:  
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/p/our-track.html  The latest red marker is the 
position up the river in Borneo.  Thanks for watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Congrats, Brian, Dellos is an absolute dream!! You guys are my heroes!! My 
dream is to do exactly what you're doing...﻿
comments.author: Felipe Ferraz

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Hahaha, I'd exchange 100 BLT's for being in your place 
right now :P
I will get out there indeed... Already have the boat (not the "final" one 
yet though) and been getting experience in small and medium trips around 
the Brazilian coast during the last 2 years. My problem is that I have a 5 
year old kid and another one coming right now hehehe so the plan is to 
arrange everything for when the kinds are a little bit older and can go 
with us! Hope you'll still be around when that happens so that we can meet 
around the globe someday! ;) Thanks for the amazing videos and fair winds 
for Delos!
comments.author: Felipe Ferraz

comments.text:
+Felipe Ferraz  Awesome man, get out there and do it.  It's an amazing 
lifestyle.  Of course with anything you do have to sacrifice some things 
but you gain so much more in return.  For example they don't sell Bacon 
here, but you can watch crocs, monkeys, and elephants from your boat.  I'd 
say it's worth it although I'm really craving a BLT right now.....
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: Nice boat !!﻿
comments.author: Jorge Calle

comments.text:
The DJI Phantom video adds flair to your videos that I already love. How 
are you uploading these? Satellite? ﻿
comments.author: David Moyers

comments.text:
Thanks! +Brian SV Delos and crew. Living my dream. And, that's what I kind 
of figured on the upload scene. Amazing that your able to pull this off. 
Safe travels.
comments.author: David Moyers

comments.text:
+David Moyers Hey David- Thanks so much for that.  Really glad to hear you 
like the footage.  We're getting some really, really cool shots and will 
hopefully be working them into videos as we go.  Satellite is just too 
expensive for us still so we buy local SIM cards and do pre-paid internet 
when we can get it.  Up this river where we did this video it took 3 days 
anchored in front of a small village to upload 15 minutes of video.  But, 
it's quite amazing to even have internet out here at all in my opinion.  
Fair Winds, and thanks for watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text: So jealous﻿

comments.text: sweet!﻿

comments.text: Inspiring.  Great boat.  Fine shape.  ﻿
